Description: Flattened pendant of green serpentine: decorated with incised lines on one side. The other side is highest in the centre, through which it has been pierced horizontally for suspension. The hole has been drilled from opposite ends to meet in the middle.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt) (said to come from)
Curator's comments: This is an example of the common form of amulet in the shape of the buprestid beetle, see L. Keimer, 'Annales du Service des Antiquitiés de l'Égypte', 31 (1931), I45ff., particularly 166-70 and pl.IV, 4; L. Keimer, 'Annales du Service des Antiquitiés de l'Égypte', 36 (1936), 89-114. Other parallels; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Naqada and Ballas' (Warminster, 1974), pl. XVIII; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tarkhan' II (London, 1914), 9 and pl. I, (1552); W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Amulets’, London (1914), 50, no. 261; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), 23 and pl.II, 7; G. Brunton, 'British Museum expedition to Middle Egypt, 1929-1931 Matmar' (London, 1948), pLXXII, 71; B. Adams, 'Ancient Hierakonpolis' Supplement (Warminster, 1974), 94, no. 204; F. Ll. Griffith, 'Liverpool Annals of Archaeology and Anthropology 8 (Liverpool, 1921), 10 and pl.IV, 8.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Walter L Lawson
